prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G34.3+0.2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of H26alpha and H32beta RRLs toward G34.3+0.2

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect RRLs with linewidths of about 60 km/s. Thus, our proposed spectral resolution is enough to resolve the profiles and, thus, to study the kinematics of G34.3+0.2. We would like to stress that we have planned to perform our observations with a spectral resolution of about 1.6 km/s, much lower than that required to constrain its kinematics. Thus, we will be able to identify molecular line emission. This is important because it is clear that molecular line confusion becomes an issue in this kind of studies, since multiple line blending (arising toward nearby hot cores) could generate broad features mimicking broad emission from RRLs.

We aim at detecting maser emission toward Utra-Compact HII regions whose radiocontinuum emission are expected to be unresolved at angular resolutions of 140 mas. We have planned to perform the observations with a high angular resolution to trace the innermost regions where RRL maser emission arise.

The requested observing time is dominated by the required time to perform observations. For that reason, we have increased our requested observing time on the source from two to five minutes. Thus, the reached rms would enough to clearly detect the H32beta RRL (SNR=32 in the peak line) at the same time that we detect the H26alpha RRL with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 100. Thus, the observations will allow us to measure the position of the centroid emission at the H26alpha peak velocities with uncertainties of about 7 mas.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G45.12+0.13 and H45.07+0.13
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of H26alpha and H32beta RRLs toward G45.12+0.13 and G45.07+0.13

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect RRLs with linewidths of about 40 km/s. Thus, our proposed spectral resolution is enough to resolve the profiles and, thus, to study the kinematics of our targets. We would like to stress that we have planned to perform our observations with a spectral resolution of about 1.6 km/s, much lower than that required to constrain its kinematics. Thus, we will be able to identify molecular line emission. This is important because it is clear that molecular line confusion becomes an issue in this kind of studies, since multiple line blending (arising toward nearby hot cores) could generate broad features mimicking broad emission from RRLs.

We aim at detecting maser emission toward Utra-Compact HII regions whose radiocontinuum emission are expected to be unresolved at angular resolutions of 140 mas. We have planned to perform the observations with a high angular resolution to trace the innermost regions where RRL maser emission arise.

The requested observing time is dominated by the required time to perform the calibrations. For that reason, we have increased our requested observing time on the source from two to five minutes. Thus, the reached rms would enough to clearly detect the H32beta RRL (with SNR>=6 in the peak line) at the same time that we detect the H26alpha RRL with a signal-to-noise ratio >=30. Thus, the observations will allow us to measure the position of the centroid emission at the H26alpha peak velocities with uncertainties of about 11 mas.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M17-UC1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of H26alpha and H32beta RRLs toward M17-UC1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect RRLs with linewidths of about 55 km/s. Thus, our proposed spectral resolution is enough to resolve the profiles and, thus, to study the kinematics of M17-UC1. We would like to stress that we have planned to perform our observations with a spectral resolution of about 1.6 km/s, much lower than that required to constrain its kinematics. Thus, we will be able to identify molecular line emission. This is important because it is clear that molecular line confusion becomes an issue in this kind of studies, since multiple line blending (arising toward nearby hot cores) could generate broad features mimicking broad emission from RRLs.

We aim at detecting maser emission toward Utra-Compact HII regions whose radiocontinuum emission are expected to be unresolved at angular resolutions of 140 mas. We have planned to perform the observations with a high angular resolution to trace the innermost regions where RRL maser emission arise.

The requested observing time is dominated by the required time to perform observations. For that reason, we have increased our requested a lower rms than that required to clearly detect the H32beta RRL. In particular, this RRL would be detected with a SNR=42. At the same time, our requested observations would provide us the detection of the H26alpha RRL with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 210. Thus, the observations will allow us to measure the position of the centroid emission at the H26alpha peak velocities with uncertainties of about 5 mas.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W49N-B1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of H26alpha and H32beta RRLs toward W49N-B1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect RRLs with linewidths of about 64 km/s. Thus, our proposed spectral resolution is enough to resolve the profiles and, thus, to study the kinematics of W49N-B1. We would like to stress that we have planned to perform our observations with a spectral resolution of about 1.6 km/s, much lower than that required to constrain its kinematics. Thus, we will be able to identify molecular line emission. This is important because it is clear that molecular line confusion becomes an issue in this kind of studies, since multiple line blending (arising toward nearby hot cores) could generate broad features mimicking broad emission from RRLs.

We aim at detecting maser emission toward Utra-Compact HII regions whose radiocontinuum emission are expected to be unresolved at angular resolutions of 140 mas. We have planned to perform the observations with a high angular resolution to trace the innermost regions where RRL maser emission arise.

The requested observing time is dominated by the required time to perform observations. Thus, the reached rms would enough to clearly detect the H32beta RRL (SNR=12 in the peak line) at the same time that we detect the H26alpha RRL with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 130. Thus, the observations will allow us to measure the position of the centroid emission at the H26alpha peak velocities with uncertainties of about 5 mas.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: K3-50A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of H26alpha and H32beta RRLs toward K3-50A

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect RRLs with linewidths of about 42.6 km/s. Thus, our proposed spectral resolution is enough to resolve the profiles and, thus, to study the kinematics of K3-50A. We would like to stress that we have planned to perform our observations with a spectral resolution of about 1.6 km/s, much lower than that required to constrain its kinematics. Thus, we will be able to identify molecular line emission. This is important because it is clear that molecular line confusion becomes an issue in this kind of studies, since multiple line blending (arising toward nearby hot cores) could generate broad features mimicking broad emission from RRLs.

We aim at detecting maser emission toward Utra-Compact HII regions whose radiocontinuum emission are expected to be unresolved at angular resolutions of 140 mas. We have planned to perform the observations with a high angular resolution to trace the innermost regions where RRL maser emission arise.

The requested observing time is dominated by the required time to perform observations. For that reason, we have increased our requested observing time on the source from two to 7.5 minutes. Thus, the reached rms would enough to clearly detect the H32beta RRL (SNR=12 in the peak line) at the same time that we detect the H26alpha RRL with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 50. Thus, the observations will allow us to measure the position of the centroid emission at the H26alpha peak velocities with uncertainties of about 10 mas.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G5.89
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of H26alpha and H32beta RRLs toward G5.89

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect RRLs with linewidths of about 75 km/s. Thus, our proposed spectral resolution is enough to resolve the profiles and, thus, to study the kinematics of G5.89. We would like to stress that we have planned to perform our observations with a spectral resolution of about 1.6 km/s, much lower than that required to constrain its kinematics. The reason for that is that we plan to identify molecular line emission. This is important because it is clear that molecular line confusion becomes an issue in this kind of studies, since multiple line blending (arising toward nearby hot cores) could generate broad features mimicking broad emission from RRLs.

We aim at detecting maser emission toward Utra-Compact HII regions whose radiocontinuum emission are expected to be unresolved at angular resolutions of 140 mas. We have planned to perform the observations with a high angular resolution to trace the innermost regions where RRL maser emission arise.

The requested observing time is dominated by the required time to perform observations. For that reason, we have increased our requested observing time on the source from two to five minutes. Thus, the reached rms would enough to clearly detect the H32beta RRL (SNR=18 in the peak line) at the same time that we detect the H26alpha RRL with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 100. Thus, the observations will allow us to measure the position of the centroid emission at the H26alpha peak velocities with uncertainties of about 7 mas.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The physical processes leading to formation of high mass stars is one of the most discussed issues in Astrophysics. This poorly known field has experienced some progress thanks to the detection of some circumstellar disks around massive stars supporting formation via monolithic collapse. The circumstellar disk with best known kinematics is that found toward the UC-HII region of MWC349A. The centroid map obtained of its RRL emission has turned out to be the best tool to study the geometry, physical characteristics and kinematics of its ionized disk and wind at small spatial scales. We intend to carry out a pilot survey of high-angular resolution by using ALMA to study the kinematics of ionized disks and winds in UC-HII regions with, potentially, RRL maser emission. However, their expected LTE intensities are enough strong to detect the Hnalpha RRLs with high signal-to-noise ratios by using ALMA and, therefore, to obtain their centroid maps with uncertainties of about a few milliarcseconds. The ALMA data would provide insight into the physical mechanisms of launching and shaping ionized winds with the ultimate goal of understanding monolithic massive star formation.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: University College London, London, University of
